revisions.rev:
{{Redirect|TRAC}} {{Primary sources|date=November 2009}} {{Infobox software | logo = [[File:Trac logo.svg|300px]] | screenshot = [[Image:Trac screenshot.png|325px]] | developer = [[Edgewall Software]] | released = {{initial release|2006|10|01}} | frequently updated = yes<!-- Release version update? Don't edit this page, just click on the version number! --> | programming language = [[Python (programming language)|Python]] | operating system = [[Cross-platform]] | genre = [[Project management software]], [[Bug tracking system]] | license = [[Modified BSD license]] | website = [http://trac.edgewall.org/ trac.edgewall.org] }} '''Trac''' is an [[open source]], web-based [[project management]] and [[bugtracker|bug-tracking]] tool. The program is inspired by [[CVSTrac]], and was originally named ''svntrac'' due to its ability to interface with [[Subversion (software)|Subversion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/TracSubversion |title=Trac and Subversion |publisher=Edgewall Trac |accessdate=2008-05-19}}</ref> It is developed and maintained by [[Edgewall Software]].
Trac is written in the [[Python (programming language)|Python programming language]]. Until mid-2005, it was available under the [[GNU General Public License]]; since version 0.9, it has been released under a [[modified BSD license]].<ref name="license">{{cite web | url=http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/TracLicense | title=TracLicense - The Trac Project | publisher=Edgewall Trac | accessdate=2007-03-06}}</ref> Both are [[free software license]]s.
== Features == Trac allows [[hyperlink]]ing information between a [[computer bug|bug]] database, [[revision control]] and [[wiki]] content. It also serves as a [[World Wide Web|web]] interface to the following [[revision control]] systems: [[Apache Subversion|Subversion]], [[Git (software)|Git]], [[Mercurial]], [[Bazaar (software)|Bazaar]], [[Perforce]] and [[Darcs]]. Prior to version 0.11 the web front end presentation of Trac was handled by the [[ClearSilver]] [[web template system|template system]]. Starting with 0.11 an in-house template system called [[Genshi (templating language)|Genshi]] is used, although compatibility with ClearSilver based plugins will remain for several versions.<ref name="clearsilver">{{cite web |date=2007-01-27 |title=ClearSilver - The Trac Project |publisher=Edgewall Trac |url=http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/ClearSilver |accessdate=2007-02-06 }}</ref>
Other features include:
* Project management (Roadmap, Milestones, etc.) * Ticket system (bug tracking, tasks, etc.) * Fine-grained permissions (since 0.11) * Timeline of all recent activity * Wiki (syntax similar to [[MoinMoin]]) * Customized reporting * [[version control system|VCS]] web interface * RSS Feeds * Multiple project support (planned for post-1.0 versions) * Environment extensibility (via Python plugins) * [[iCalendar]] export<ref>{{cite web |url=http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/TracRoadmap |title=The Trac Roadmap |accessdate=14 September 2009 |publisher=Edgewall Trac}}</ref> * Multiple Repository Support per environment (since 0.12) * Interface [[localization]]s (since 0.12)
== Adoption ==
Trac is reported to have more than 450 major installations worldwide.<ref name="tracusers">{{cite web |date=2008-06-25 |title=Who uses Trac?|publisher=Edgewall Trac |url=http://trac.edgewall.org/wiki/TracUsers |accessdate=2008-06-25 }}</ref> Among the users of Trac is [[NASA]]'s [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]], which reports that it uses this tool to manage various deep space and near space projects; [[Twisted (software)|Twisted]], an asynchronous networking framework implemented in Python; the [[Dojo Toolkit]], one of the popular [[Open source]] [[JavaScript library]] projects; [[Piwik]], a free software equivalent to services like [[Google Analytics]]; and [[WordPress]], the popular blogging platform, all use Trac for bug tracking and as a source tree viewer. Some projects also use Trac's wiki.
